comment: Definitions match but object type is broader.
Definitions and types match.  Note, an identical object also exists at /eml/annotations/annotation/valueURI/@label and is linked to the EML dataset property through a "references" attribute.

No match can be found.  Note, it the identifier property value is a DOI, the citation text can be automatically generated by querying a DOI URL with an Accept Header of 'text/x-bibliography'.

Definitions match but object type is narrower.  Note, an identical object also exists at /eml/annotations/annotation/valueURI and is linked to the EML attribute property through a "references" attribute.

Definition doesn't match but object type does.  The subject represents the actual minimum value of the measured variable, whereas the object represents the minimum permissible value, which may in fact differ from the actual minimum value.

Definition doesn't match but object type does.  The subject represents the actual maximum value of the measured variable, whereas the object represents the maximum permissible value, which may in fact differ from the actual maximum value.

Definitions match but object type is narrower.  An exact match between the subject and object is formed when the object's "function" attribute (/element(*,PhysicalType)/distribution/online/url/@function) has a value of "download". See: https://eml.ecoinformatics.org/schema/eml-resource_xsd.html#OnlineType_url

No match can be found.  There is no single field that lists the format type for a data object in the EML standard. Rather, EML offers a choice of four data types within which properties provide information for a user to download and parse it.
Definitions and types match.  Note, the object's size and @unit properties must be concatenated with a blank space separator to match the subject's definition.
Definitions and types match.  Note, the object's calendarDate and time properties must be concatenated with a "T" separator to match the subject's definition.
Definitions and types match.  Note, the object's properties must be concatenated with a "/" to match the subject's definition.

subject_category: Spatial Coverage (For declaring a spatial reference system)
comment: This is a fixed constant value specified in the SOSO guidelines.

subject_category: Spatial Coverage (For declaring a spatial reference system)
comment: This is a fixed constant value specified in the SOSO guidelines.  This is a default value and can be changed. The recommended list is at: https://github.com/ESIPFed/science-on-schema.org/blob/master/guides/Dataset.md#spatial-reference-systems.
Definitions and types match.  Requires logic to determine if the coordinates match and indeed form a point.
Definitions and types match.  Requires logic to determine if the coordinates match and indeed form a point.

Definitions and types match.  Requires logic to determine if the upper and lower bounds match to form a single value.  Note, it appears that the subject requires WGS 84 it is unclear if this requirement is met by EML. For this reason the match type is given a low confidence.
Definitions match but object type is narrower.  Requires the concatenation of the object properties in the listed order and with a blank space separator.

Definitions and types match.  Requires logic to reverse the ordering of lat/lon values of the object to match the subject's definition. The object's ordered pairs list longitude then latitude, whereas the subject's ordered pairs represents latitude then longitude.
Definitions match but object type is broader.  Note, the object's value can be a URL and thus form an exact match.

Definitions match but object type is broader.  Duplicates content from schema:isBasedOn because as the SOSO guidelines state "there is utility in expressing the relationship with both predicates for consumers that might only be looking for one or the other."
